trans-unit.source: Shard Elasticity
trans-unit.target: Shard Elasticity

trans-unit.source: Explains concepts and gives examples behind shard elasticity, the ability to scale out Azure SQL databases easily.
trans-unit.target: Explains concepts and gives examples behind shard elasticity, the ability to scale out Azure SQL databases easily.

trans-unit.source: Shard elasticity
trans-unit.target: Shard elasticity

trans-unit.source: **Shard elasticity** enables application developers to dynamically grow and shrink database resources according to need, enabling one to optimize the performance of their applications, and also to minimize costs.
trans-unit.target: **Shard elasticity** enables application developers to dynamically grow and shrink database resources according to need, enabling one to optimize the performance of their applications, and also to minimize costs.

trans-unit.source: The combination of the **Elastic Database tools** for Azure SQL Database along with the [Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn741340.aspx) provides very compelling elasticity scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The combination of the **Elastic Database tools** for Azure SQL Database along with the [Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn741340.aspx) provides very compelling elasticity scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Elastic database tools enable horizontal scaling - a design pattern in which databases (also [known as "shards”](sql-database-elastic-scale-glossary.md)) are added or removed from a shard set to grow or shrink capacity.
trans-unit.target: Elastic database tools enable horizontal scaling - a design pattern in which databases (also [known as "shards”](sql-database-elastic-scale-glossary.md)) are added or removed from a shard set to grow or shrink capacity.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the SQL Database service tiers provide **vertical scaling** capabilities in that a single database's resources can scale up or down to appropriately match demand.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the SQL Database service tiers provide **vertical scaling** capabilities in that a single database's resources can scale up or down to appropriately match demand.

trans-unit.source: Together, the vertical scaling of a single shard and the horizontal scaling of many shards, affords application developers a very flexible environment that can scale to meet performance, capacity and cost-optimization needs.
trans-unit.target: Together, the vertical scaling of a single shard and the horizontal scaling of many shards, affords application developers a very flexible environment that can scale to meet performance, capacity and cost-optimization needs.

trans-unit.source: With the newly introduced **elastic database pools** capability, vertical scaling is even simpler to achieve.
trans-unit.target: With the newly introduced **elastic database pools** capability, vertical scaling is even simpler to achieve.

trans-unit.source: Pools allow an individual database’s resource consumption to grow or shrink *automatically* within a budget shared among the entire pool.
trans-unit.target: Pools allow an individual database’s resource consumption to grow or shrink *automatically* within a budget shared among the entire pool.

trans-unit.source: For applications that choose not to take advantage of elastic database pools, this article will describe other techniques for implementing policy-based mechanics for managing vertical scaling, as well as some common scenarios for automating horizontal scaling operations.
trans-unit.target: For applications that choose not to take advantage of elastic database pools, this article will describe other techniques for implementing policy-based mechanics for managing vertical scaling, as well as some common scenarios for automating horizontal scaling operations.

trans-unit.source: Horizontal scaling example: concert spike
trans-unit.target: Horizontal scaling example: concert spike

trans-unit.source: A canonical scenario for horizontal scaling is an application that processes transactions for concert tickets.
trans-unit.target: A canonical scenario for horizontal scaling is an application that processes transactions for concert tickets.

trans-unit.source: Under normal customer volume, the application uses minimal database resources to handle purchase transactions.
trans-unit.target: Under normal customer volume, the application uses minimal database resources to handle purchase transactions.

trans-unit.source: However, when tickets go on sale for a popular concert, a single database cannot handle the large spike in customer demand.
trans-unit.target: However, when tickets go on sale for a popular concert, a single database cannot handle the large spike in customer demand.

trans-unit.source: To process the dramatic increase in transactions, the application scales horizontally.
trans-unit.target: To process the dramatic increase in transactions, the application scales horizontally.

trans-unit.source: The application can now distribute the transaction load across many shards.
trans-unit.target: The application can now distribute the transaction load across many shards.

trans-unit.source: When the additional resources are no longer needed, the database tier shrinks back for normal usage.
trans-unit.target: When the additional resources are no longer needed, the database tier shrinks back for normal usage.

trans-unit.source: Here horizontal scaling enables an application to scale-out to match customer demand and scale-in when the resources are no longer needed.
trans-unit.target: Here horizontal scaling enables an application to scale-out to match customer demand and scale-in when the resources are no longer needed.

trans-unit.source: Vertical scaling example: telemetry
trans-unit.target: Vertical scaling example: telemetry

trans-unit.source: A canonical scenario for vertical scaling is an application that uses a **shard set** to store operational telemetry.
trans-unit.target: A canonical scenario for vertical scaling is an application that uses a **shard set** to store operational telemetry.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, it is better to co-locate all telemetry data for a single day on a single shard.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, it is better to co-locate all telemetry data for a single day on a single shard.

trans-unit.source: In this application, data for the current day is ingested into a shard and a new shard is provisioned for subsequent days.
trans-unit.target: In this application, data for the current day is ingested into a shard and a new shard is provisioned for subsequent days.

trans-unit.source: The operational data can then be aged and queried as appropriate.
trans-unit.target: The operational data can then be aged and queried as appropriate.

trans-unit.source: To ingest telemetry data at high loads, it is better to employ a higher service tier.
trans-unit.target: To ingest telemetry data at high loads, it is better to employ a higher service tier.

trans-unit.source: In other words, a Premium database is better than a Basic database.
trans-unit.target: In other words, a Premium database is better than a Basic database.

trans-unit.source: Once the database reaches its capacity, it switches from ingestion to analysis and reporting.
trans-unit.target: Once the database reaches its capacity, it switches from ingestion to analysis and reporting.

trans-unit.source: For that, the Standard tier's performance is equal to the task.
trans-unit.target: For that, the Standard tier's performance is equal to the task.

trans-unit.source: Thus one can vertically scale down the service tier on shards (other than the most recently created one) in order to fit the lower performance requirements for older data.
trans-unit.target: Thus one can vertically scale down the service tier on shards (other than the most recently created one) in order to fit the lower performance requirements for older data.

trans-unit.source: Vertical scaling can also be used to increase the performance of a single database in order to achieve increased performance.
trans-unit.target: Vertical scaling can also be used to increase the performance of a single database in order to achieve increased performance.

trans-unit.source: An example is a tax filing application.
trans-unit.target: An example is a tax filing application.

trans-unit.source: At filing time, it is better to keep a single customer’s data all on the same database and increase the performance of that shard.
trans-unit.target: At filing time, it is better to keep a single customer’s data all on the same database and increase the performance of that shard.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the application, vertically scaling up and down resources is advantageous to optimize for both cost and performance requirements.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the application, vertically scaling up and down resources is advantageous to optimize for both cost and performance requirements.

trans-unit.source: Together, both horizontal and vertical scaling of the database tier are at the core of application scalability and shard elasticity.
trans-unit.target: Together, both horizontal and vertical scaling of the database tier are at the core of application scalability and shard elasticity.

trans-unit.source: This document provides the context for shard elasticity scenarios as well as references to example implementations of both vertical and horizontal scaling.
trans-unit.target: This document provides the context for shard elasticity scenarios as well as references to example implementations of both vertical and horizontal scaling.

trans-unit.source: To horizontally scale, a rule (based on date or database size) is used to provision a new shard and register it with the shard map, thus growing the database tier horizontally.
trans-unit.target: To horizontally scale, a rule (based on date or database size) is used to provision a new shard and register it with the shard map, thus growing the database tier horizontally.

trans-unit.source: Secondly, to scale vertically, a second rule is implemented in which any shard that is older than one day is downgraded from Premium Edition to a Standard or Basic Edition.
trans-unit.target: Secondly, to scale vertically, a second rule is implemented in which any shard that is older than one day is downgraded from Premium Edition to a Standard or Basic Edition.

trans-unit.source: Consider the telemetry scenario again: the application shards by date.
trans-unit.target: Consider the telemetry scenario again: the application shards by date.

trans-unit.source: It collects telemetry data continuously, requiring a high performance edition at loading time, but lower performance as the data ages.
trans-unit.target: It collects telemetry data continuously, requiring a high performance edition at loading time, but lower performance as the data ages.

trans-unit.source: The current day’s data [Tnow] is written to a high performance database (Premium).
trans-unit.target: The current day’s data [Tnow] is written to a high performance database (Premium).

trans-unit.source: Once the clock strikes midnight, the previous day’s shard (now [T-1]) is no longer be used for ingestion.
trans-unit.target: Once the clock strikes midnight, the previous day’s shard (now [T-1]) is no longer be used for ingestion.

trans-unit.source: The current data is ingested by the current [Tnow].
trans-unit.target: The current data is ingested by the current [Tnow].

trans-unit.source: In advance of the next day, a new shard must be provisioned and registered with the shard map ([T+1]).
trans-unit.target: In advance of the next day, a new shard must be provisioned and registered with the shard map ([T+1]).

trans-unit.source: This can be done by either provisioning a new shard in advance of every new day or by provisioning a new shard when the current shard ([Tnow]) nears its maximum capacity.
trans-unit.target: This can be done by either provisioning a new shard in advance of every new day or by provisioning a new shard when the current shard ([Tnow]) nears its maximum capacity.

trans-unit.source: Using either of these methods preserves the data locality for all telemetry written for a particular day.
trans-unit.target: Using either of these methods preserves the data locality for all telemetry written for a particular day.

trans-unit.source: Per-hour sharding could also be applied for finer granularity.
trans-unit.target: Per-hour sharding could also be applied for finer granularity.

trans-unit.source: Once a new shard is provisioned, and because [T-1] is used for querying and reporting, it is desirable to reduce the performance level of the database reduce costs.
trans-unit.target: Once a new shard is provisioned, and because [T-1] is used for querying and reporting, it is desirable to reduce the performance level of the database reduce costs.
